did.abstract: Leading authority on international refugee law and related aspects of human rights and public international law. The collection includes materials related to his research on refugee law and other aspects of human rights.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Donated by James C. Hathaway (donor no. 11239) in March, 2015.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The James C. Hathaway papers are open for research except for certain records restricted by statute or university policy. Restricted material includes personnel-related files, including search, review, promotion, and tenure files; student educational records; client/patient records; and records of executive officers of the university.

The James C. Hathaway papers include restricted material in the following categories:
Student Academic Records -- Boxes 31-32

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, James C. Hathaway papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: James C. Hathaway is a leading authority on international refugee law and related aspects of human rights and public international law. Hathaway earned his Bachelor of Law from Osgoode Hall Law School of York University, and received his Doctor of the Science of Law and Master of Laws from Columbia University. Hathaway joined the University of Michigan Law School faculty in 1998. He is the James E. and Sarah A. Degan Professor of Law, the founding director of the Michigan Law's Program in Refugee and Asylum Law, Distinguished Visiting Professor of International Refugee Law at the University of Amsterdam, and Professorial Fellow of the University of Melbourne. Hathaway served as a dean of the Melbourne Law School, where he established Australia's first all-graduate law program from 2008 to 2010. He has been appointed as a visiting professor at the universities of Cairo, California, Macerata, Toronto, and Tokyo. Prior to joining the University of Michigan faculty, Hathaway served as a founding faculty member of the Ecole de droit de I'Universite de Moncton in Canada, the world's first French-language common law program of study, from 1981 to 1984. He served as a Professor of Law and Associate Dean of York University's Osgoode Hall Law School from 1984 to 1998. Hathaway has published more than 70 journal articles, The Law of Refugee Status (1991), The Rights of Refugees Under International Law (2005), and other works.

arrangement.p: The materials are arranged into three series: Research, Manuscripts, and Student Research.

scopecontent.p: The James C. Hathaway papers consists of 32.3 linear feet of materials related to his research on refugee law and other aspects of human rights spanning the years 1952 to 2015.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Human rights.
Human rights advocacy.
International law and human rights.
The law of refugee status, 1991.
Refugee families.
Refugee issues.
Refugees.
Respect for persons--Law and legislation.
The rights of refugees under international law, 2005.

scopecontent.p: The Research series (1952-1999, 3.8 linear feet) is divided into three subseries: Canadian Legal Documents, Human Rights Research, and European Law Paperwork. Each subseries contain photocopies of research conducted by Hathaway. These materials contain annotations, memos, and other notes written by or sent to Hathaway.

scopecontent.p: The Manuscripts series (1989-2010, 26.5 linear feet) is divided into three sub-series: Rights of Refugees under International Law, Law of Refugee Status, and "Commentary on the Refugee Convention, 1951." The series contains research materials for two of Hathaway's publications, Law of Refugee Status (1991) and Rights of Refugees under International Law (2005). The first two sub-series contain annotated photocopies of case studies, journal articles, memos, and correspondence. The third sub-series contains the original manuscript copy of Atle Grahl-Madsen's groundbreaking book Commentary on the Refugee Convention 1951. Hathaway distinguishes Grahl-Madsen's work as the inspiration for his own writings.

scopecontent.p: The Student Research (2004-2012, 2 linear feet) consists of student papers from a variety of Hathaway's courses. The papers were developed for a seminar in international refugee law and were used as supplemental research for Hathaway's manuscripts.
